segment.source: Learn about the move and draw commands (a mini-language) that you can use to specify path geometries as a XAML attribute value.
segment.target: Learn about the move and draw commands (a mini-language) that you can use to specify path geometries as a XAML attribute value.

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Learn about the move and draw commands (a mini-language) that you can use to specify path geometries as a XAML attribute value.
segment.target: Learn about the move and draw commands (a mini-language) that you can use to specify path geometries as a XAML attribute value.

segment.source: Move and draw commands are used by many design and graphics tools that can output a vector graphic or shape, as a serialization and interchange format.
segment.target: Move and draw commands are used by many design and graphics tools that can output a vector graphic or shape, as a serialization and interchange format.

segment.source: Properties that use move and draw command strings
segment.target: Properties that use move and draw command strings

segment.source: The move and draw command syntax is supported by an internal type converter for XAML, which parses the commands and produces a run-time graphics representation.
segment.target: The move and draw command syntax is supported by an internal type converter for XAML, which parses the commands and produces a run-time graphics representation.

segment.source: This representation is basically a finished set of vectors that is ready for presentation.
segment.target: This representation is basically a finished set of vectors that is ready for presentation.

segment.source: The vectors themselves don't complete the presentation details; you'll still need to set other values on the elements.
segment.target: The vectors themselves don't complete the presentation details; you'll still need to set other values on the elements.

segment.source: For a Path object you also need values for Fill, Stroke, and other properties, and then that Path must be connected to the visual tree somehow.
segment.target: For a Path object you also need values for Fill, Stroke, and other properties, and then that Path must be connected to the visual tree somehow.

segment.source: For a PathIcon object, set the Foreground property.
segment.target: For a PathIcon object, set the Foreground property.

segment.source: There are two properties in the Windows Runtime that can use a string representing move and draw commands: Path.Data and PathIcon.Data.
segment.target: There are two properties in the Windows Runtime that can use a string representing move and draw commands: Path.Data and PathIcon.Data.

segment.source: If you set one of these properties by specifying move and draw commands, you typically set it as a XAML attribute value along with other required attributes of that element.
segment.target: If you set one of these properties by specifying move and draw commands, you typically set it as a XAML attribute value along with other required attributes of that element.

segment.source: Without getting into the specifics, here's what that looks like:
segment.target: Without getting into the specifics, here's what that looks like:

segment.source: PathGeometry.Figures can also use move and draw commands.
segment.target: PathGeometry.Figures can also use move and draw commands.

segment.source: You might combine a PathGeometry object that uses move and draw commands with other Geometry types in a GeometryGroup object, which you'd then use as the value for Path.Data.
segment.target: You might combine a PathGeometry object that uses move and draw commands with other Geometry types in a GeometryGroup object, which you'd then use as the value for Path.Data.

segment.source: But that isn't nearly as common as using move and draw commands for attribute-defined data.
segment.target: But that isn't nearly as common as using move and draw commands for attribute-defined data.

segment.source: Using move and draw commands versus using a PathGeometry
segment.target: Using move and draw commands versus using a PathGeometry

segment.source: For Windows Runtime XAML, the move and draw commands produce a PathGeometry with a single PathFigure object with a Figures property value.
segment.target: For Windows Runtime XAML, the move and draw commands produce a PathGeometry with a single PathFigure object with a Figures property value.

segment.source: Each draw command produces a PathSegment derived class in that single PathFigure's Segments collection, the move command changes the StartPoint, and existence of a close command sets IsClosed to true.
segment.target: Each draw command produces a PathSegment derived class in that single PathFigure's Segments collection, the move command changes the StartPoint, and existence of a close command sets IsClosed to true.

segment.source: You can navigate this structure as an object model if you examine the Data values at run time.
segment.target: You can navigate this structure as an object model if you examine the Data values at run time.

segment.source: The syntax for move and draw commands can be summarized like this:
segment.target: The syntax for move and draw commands can be summarized like this:

segment.source: Start with an optional fill rule.
segment.target: Start with an optional fill rule.

segment.source: Typically you specify this only if you don't want the EvenOdd default.
segment.target: Typically you specify this only if you don't want the EvenOdd default.

segment.source: Specify one or more draw commands.
segment.target: Specify one or more draw commands.

segment.source: You can omit a close command , but that would leave your figure open (that's uncommon).
segment.target: You can omit a close command , but that would leave your figure open (that's uncommon).

segment.source: General rules of this syntax are:
segment.target: General rules of this syntax are:

segment.source: Each command is represented by exactly one letter.
segment.target: Each command is represented by exactly one letter.

segment.source: That letter can be upper-case or lower-case.
segment.target: That letter can be upper-case or lower-case.

segment.source: Each command except the close command is typically followed by one or more numbers.
segment.target: Each command except the close command is typically followed by one or more numbers.

segment.source: If more than one number for a command, separate with a comma or space.
segment.target: If more than one number for a command, separate with a comma or space.

segment.source: Many of the draw commands use points, where you provide an x,y value.
segment.target: Many of the draw commands use points, where you provide an x,y value.

segment.source: Whenever you see a \*points placeholder you can assume you're giving two decimal values for the x,y value of a point.
segment.target: Whenever you see a \*points placeholder you can assume you're giving two decimal values for the x,y value of a point.

segment.source: White space can often be omitted when the result is not ambiguous.
segment.target: White space can often be omitted when the result is not ambiguous.

segment.source: You can in fact omit all white space if you use commas as your separator for all number sets (points and size).
segment.target: You can in fact omit all white space if you use commas as your separator for all number sets (points and size).

segment.source: For example, this usage is legal: .
segment.target: For example, this usage is legal: .

segment.source: But it's more typical to include white space between commands for clarity.
segment.target: But it's more typical to include white space between commands for clarity.

segment.source: Don't use commas as the decimal point for decimal numbers; the command string is interpreted by XAML and doesn't account for culture-specific number-formatting conventions that differ from those used in the en-us locale.
segment.target: Don't use commas as the decimal point for decimal numbers; the command string is interpreted by XAML and doesn't account for culture-specific number-formatting conventions that differ from those used in the en-us locale.

segment.source: There are two possible values for the optional fill rule: F0 or F1.
segment.target: There are two possible values for the optional fill rule: F0 or F1.

segment.source: (The F is always uppercase.) F0 is the default value; it produces EvenOdd fill behavior, so you don't typically specify it.
segment.target: (The F is always uppercase.) F0 is the default value; it produces EvenOdd fill behavior, so you don't typically specify it.

segment.source: Use F1 to get the Nonzero fill behavior.
segment.target: Use F1 to get the Nonzero fill behavior.

segment.source: These fill values align with the values of the FillRule enumeration.
segment.target: These fill values align with the values of the FillRule enumeration.

segment.source: Specifies the start point of a new figure.
segment.target: Specifies the start point of a new figure.

segment.source: The start point of a new figure.
segment.target: The start point of a new figure.

segment.source: An uppercase M indicates that startPoint is an absolute coordinate; a lowercase m indicates that startPoint is an offset to the previous point, or (0,0) if there was no previous point.
segment.target: An uppercase M indicates that startPoint is an absolute coordinate; a lowercase m indicates that startPoint is an offset to the previous point, or (0,0) if there was no previous point.

segment.source: Note It's legal to specify multiple points after the move command.
segment.target: Note It's legal to specify multiple points after the move command.

segment.source: A line is drawn to those points as if you specified the line command.
segment.target: A line is drawn to those points as if you specified the line command.

segment.source: However that's not a recommended style; use the dedicated line command instead.
segment.target: However that's not a recommended style; use the dedicated line command instead.

segment.source: A draw command can consist of several shape commands: line, horizontal line, vertical line, cubic Bezier curve, quadratic Bezier curve, smooth cubic Bezier curve, smooth quadratic Bezier curve, and elliptical arc.
segment.target: A draw command can consist of several shape commands: line, horizontal line, vertical line, cubic Bezier curve, quadratic Bezier curve, smooth cubic Bezier curve, smooth quadratic Bezier curve, and elliptical arc.

segment.source: For all draw commands, case matters.
segment.target: For all draw commands, case matters.

segment.source: Uppercase letters denote absolute coordinates and lowercase letters denote coordinates relative to the previous command.
segment.target: Uppercase letters denote absolute coordinates and lowercase letters denote coordinates relative to the previous command.

segment.source: The control points for a segment are relative to the end point of the preceding segment.
segment.target: The control points for a segment are relative to the end point of the preceding segment.

segment.source: When sequentially entering more than one command of the same type, you can omit the duplicate command entry.
segment.target: When sequentially entering more than one command of the same type, you can omit the duplicate command entry.

segment.source: Creates a straight line between the current point and the specified end point.
segment.target: Creates a straight line between the current point and the specified end point.

segment.source: and are examples of valid line commands.
segment.target: and are examples of valid line commands.

segment.source: Defines the equivalent of a LineGeometry object.
segment.target: Defines the equivalent of a LineGeometry object.

segment.source: The end point of the line.
segment.target: The end point of the line.

segment.source: Creates a horizontal line between the current point and the specified x-coordinate.
segment.target: Creates a horizontal line between the current point and the specified x-coordinate.

segment.source: is an example of a valid horizontal line command.
segment.target: is an example of a valid horizontal line command.

segment.source: The x-coordinate of the end point of the line.
segment.target: The x-coordinate of the end point of the line.

segment.source: Creates a vertical line between the current point and the specified y-coordinate.
segment.target: Creates a vertical line between the current point and the specified y-coordinate.

segment.source: is an example of a valid vertical line command.
segment.target: is an example of a valid vertical line command.

segment.source: The y-coordinate of the end point of the line.
segment.target: The y-coordinate of the end point of the line.

segment.source: Creates a cubic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point by using the two specified control points (controlPoint1 and controlPoint2).
segment.target: Creates a cubic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point by using the two specified control points (controlPoint1 and controlPoint2).

segment.source: is an example of a valid curve command.
segment.target: is an example of a valid curve command.

segment.source: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry object with a BezierSegment object.
segment.target: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry object with a BezierSegment object.

segment.source: The first control point of the curve, which determines the starting tangent of the curve.
segment.target: The first control point of the curve, which determines the starting tangent of the curve.

segment.source: The second control point of the curve, which determines the ending tangent of the curve.
segment.target: The second control point of the curve, which determines the ending tangent of the curve.

segment.source: The point to which the curve is drawn.
segment.target: The point to which the curve is drawn.

segment.source: Creates a quadratic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point by using the specified control point (controlPoint).
segment.target: Creates a quadratic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point by using the specified control point (controlPoint).

segment.source: is an example of a valid quadratic Bézier curve command.
segment.target: is an example of a valid quadratic Bézier curve command.

segment.source: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a QuadraticBezierSegment.
segment.target: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a QuadraticBezierSegment.

segment.source: The control point of the curve, which determines the starting and ending tangents of the curve.
segment.target: The control point of the curve, which determines the starting and ending tangents of the curve.

segment.source: The point to which the curve is drawn.
segment.target: The point to which the curve is drawn.

segment.source: Creates a cubic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point.
segment.target: Creates a cubic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point.

segment.source: The first control point is assumed to be the reflection of the second control point of the previous command relative to the current point.
segment.target: The first control point is assumed to be the reflection of the second control point of the previous command relative to the current point.

segment.source: If there is no previous command or if the previous command was not a cubic Bézier curve command or a smooth cubic Bézier curve command, assume the first control point is coincident with the current point.
segment.target: If there is no previous command or if the previous command was not a cubic Bézier curve command or a smooth cubic Bézier curve command, assume the first control point is coincident with the current point.

segment.source: The second control point—the control point for the end of the curve—is specified by controlPoint2.
segment.target: The second control point—the control point for the end of the curve—is specified by controlPoint2.

segment.source: For example, is a valid smooth cubic Bézier curve command.
segment.target: For example, is a valid smooth cubic Bézier curve command.

segment.source: This command defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a BezierSegment where there was preceding curve segment.
segment.target: This command defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a BezierSegment where there was preceding curve segment.

segment.source: The control point of the curve, which determines the ending tangent of the curve.
segment.target: The control point of the curve, which determines the ending tangent of the curve.

segment.source: The point to which the curve is drawn.
segment.target: The point to which the curve is drawn.

segment.source: Creates a quadratic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point.
segment.target: Creates a quadratic Bézier curve between the current point and the specified end point.

segment.source: The control point is assumed to be the reflection of the control point of the previous command relative to the current point.
segment.target: The control point is assumed to be the reflection of the control point of the previous command relative to the current point.

segment.source: If there is no previous command or if the previous command was not a quadratic Bézier curve command or a smooth quadratic Bézier curve command, the control point is coincident with the current point.
segment.target: If there is no previous command or if the previous command was not a quadratic Bézier curve command or a smooth quadratic Bézier curve command, the control point is coincident with the current point.

segment.source: This command defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a QuadraticBezierSegment where there was preceding curve segment.
segment.target: This command defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with a QuadraticBezierSegment where there was preceding curve segment.

segment.source: The control point of the curve, which determines the starting and tangent of the curve.
segment.target: The control point of the curve, which determines the starting and tangent of the curve.

segment.source: The point to which the curve is drawn.
segment.target: The point to which the curve is drawn.

segment.source: Creates an elliptical arc between the current point and the specified end point.
segment.target: Creates an elliptical arc between the current point and the specified end point.

segment.source: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with an ArcSegment.
segment.target: Defines the equivalent of a PathGeometry with an ArcSegment.

segment.source: The x-radius and y-radius of the arc.
segment.target: The x-radius and y-radius of the arc.

segment.source: The rotation of the ellipse, in degrees.
segment.target: The rotation of the ellipse, in degrees.

segment.source: Set to 1 if the angle of the arc should be 180 degrees or greater; otherwise, set to 0.
segment.target: Set to 1 if the angle of the arc should be 180 degrees or greater; otherwise, set to 0.

segment.source: Set to 1 if the arc is drawn in a positive-angle direction; otherwise, set to 0.
segment.target: Set to 1 if the arc is drawn in a positive-angle direction; otherwise, set to 0.

segment.source: The point to which the arc is drawn.
segment.target: The point to which the arc is drawn.

segment.source: Ends the current figure and creates a line that connects the current point to the starting point of the figure.
segment.target: Ends the current figure and creates a line that connects the current point to the starting point of the figure.

segment.source: This command creates a line-join (corner) between the last segment and the first segment of the figure.
segment.target: This command creates a line-join (corner) between the last segment and the first segment of the figure.

segment.source: Describes the x-coordinate and y-coordinate of a point.
segment.target: Describes the x-coordinate and y-coordinate of a point.

segment.source: Instead of a standard numerical value, you can also use the following special values.
segment.target: Instead of a standard numerical value, you can also use the following special values.

segment.source: Instead of using decimals or integers, you can use scientific notation.
segment.target: Instead of using decimals or integers, you can use scientific notation.

segment.source: For example, is a valid value.
segment.target: For example, is a valid value.

segment.source: Design tools that produce move and draw commands
segment.target: Design tools that produce move and draw commands

segment.source: Using the Pen tool and other drawing tools in Blend for Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 will usually produce a Path object, with move and draw commands.
segment.target: Using the Pen tool and other drawing tools in Blend for Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 will usually produce a Path object, with move and draw commands.

segment.source: You might see existing move and draw command data in some of the control parts defined in the Windows Runtime XAML default templates for controls.
segment.target: You might see existing move and draw command data in some of the control parts defined in the Windows Runtime XAML default templates for controls.

segment.source: For example, some controls use a PathIcon that has the data defined as move and draw commands.
segment.target: For example, some controls use a PathIcon that has the data defined as move and draw commands.

segment.source: There are exporters or plug-ins available for other commonly used vector-graphics design tools that can output the vector in XAML form.
segment.target: There are exporters or plug-ins available for other commonly used vector-graphics design tools that can output the vector in XAML form.

segment.source: These usually create Path objects in a layout container, with move and draw commands for Path.Data.
segment.target: These usually create Path objects in a layout container, with move and draw commands for Path.Data.

segment.source: There may be multiple Path elements in the XAML so that different brushes can be applied.
segment.target: There may be multiple Path elements in the XAML so that different brushes can be applied.

segment.source: These exporters or plug-ins were originally written for Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) XAML, but that aspect of XAML syntax is identical with Windows Runtime XAML.
segment.target: These exporters or plug-ins were originally written for Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) XAML, but that aspect of XAML syntax is identical with Windows Runtime XAML.

segment.source: You can probably use chunks of XAML from an exporter and paste them right into a Windows Runtime XAML page.
segment.target: You can probably use chunks of XAML from an exporter and paste them right into a Windows Runtime XAML page.

segment.source: (However, you won't be able to use a RadialGradientBrush, if that was part of the converted XAML, because Windows Runtime XAML doesn't support that brush.)
segment.target: (However, you won't be able to use a RadialGradientBrush, if that was part of the converted XAML, because Windows Runtime XAML doesn't support that brush.)
